Having explained the basis of what is to be known, how should the characteristics of what is to be known be seen?
This is briefly of three kinds:
First, the characteristics of dependent arising, second, the characteristics of imagined grasping, and third, the characteristics of perfect completion.
The commentary states:
Having explained the basis of what is to be known means it will not be explained again.
This refers to the characteristics of what is to be known.
Briefly of three kinds means that all dharmas must have the distinctions of what is to be known, what is to be eliminated, and what is to be realized.
The characteristics of dependent arising means that based on karma and afflictions, the grasped and the grasper are imagined and arise in accordance with others.
What is indicated by such characteristics?
It means the characteristics of dependent arising.
The characteristics of imagined grasping means that which is forever non-existent.
It is eternally devoid of characteristics because it is the characteristic of the nature of the self and dharmas that are grasped and the grasper, which are imagined.
How can that which does not exist be characterized?
Because it is just so discriminated.
The BhagavÄn has said:
Up to not knowing that which really exists as really existing, and not knowing that which does not exist as not existing;
Thus knowing that which really exists as really existing, and knowing that which is not really existing as not really existing.

The characteristic of the perfected is the nature of the non-existence of the self and dharmas that are grasped and the grasper, which are imagined, in that very [nature of the dependent]. It is the nature of the object that is understood using that as a measure.

In that thorough knowledge, one is able to thoroughly discriminate that which is imagined as definitely non-existent, because there is a contradictory nature and because it is not the nature of an object.
The treatise says:
What is the characteristic of the dependent in this context?
It refers to the various consciousnesses that are included in false discrimination, with the Älaya consciousness as their seeds.
What is it?

Namely, the consciousness of body, the experiencer of body, the consciousness of what is experienced by that [experiencer], the consciousness of the experiencer of that [what is experienced], the consciousness of world, the consciousness of number, the consciousness of place, the consciousness of speech, the consciousness of the distinction between self and other, and the consciousness of death and rebirth in good and evil destinies.

Among them, if it is the consciousness of body, the experiencer of body, the consciousness of what is experienced by that [experiencer], the consciousness of the experiencer of that [what is experienced], the consciousness of world, the consciousness of number, the consciousness of place, and the consciousness of speech, this is due to the seeds of perfuming by names and expressions.
If it is the consciousness of the distinction between self and other, this is due to the seeds of perfuming by the view of self.
If it is the consciousness of death and rebirth in good and evil destinies, this is due to the seeds of perfuming by the factors of existence.
Due to these consciousnesses, all the characteristics of dependent arising included in the defilements of the various realms and destinies, and false discrimination, are all manifested.

All these consciousnesses are included in false imagination, have consciousness only as their nature, are nonexistent, and are the basis for the appearance of unreal objects. This is called the imagined identity.
What is the dependent on others identity?
It is the appearance of objects as real entities in consciousness only, in the absence of objects.
What is the perfected identity?
It is the absence of the nature of the appearance of objects in that dependent on others identity.
The Commentary explains:
The consciousness of the body, the possessor of the body, and the experiencer refers to the six internal sense bases such as the eyes, as will be explained later.

The consciousness of the possessor of the body is the sense base of the mental faculty that supports the first five material consciousnesses, such as visual consciousness, and the consciousness of the experiencer is the sense base of the mental faculty that supports the sixth mental consciousness. The consciousness that experiences is the six external sense bases such as form, as will be explained later. The consciousness that is experienced is the six consciousnesses, as will be explained later.
The consciousness of the world refers to the appearance of the three time periods.
The consciousness of number refers to the appearance of numbers such as one, etc.
The consciousness of location refers to the appearance of villages, gardens, etc.
The consciousness of speech refers to the appearance of speech such as seeing, hearing, knowing, etc.

The consciousness of self and other distinctions refers to the consciousness of the body, etc., where the grasping of I and mine continues uninterrupted, because there are distinctions such as grasping I and mine and other and others'.
The consciousness of death and rebirth in good and evil destinies refers to the appearance of death and rebirth in the heavens, among humans, and in the hells, as animals, hungry ghosts, etc.

Here, if the body, the experiencer of the body, etc., up to the consciousness of speech are due to the seeds of perfuming by names and expressions, it means that the body, etc., are all manifested by consciousness due to the seeds of perfuming by names and expressions, because there are no separate things.

If the consciousness of distinctions between self and other is due to the seeds of perfuming by the view of self, it means that it is manifested due to the cause of the perfuming by the view of self in defiled mind.

If it is said that the consciousness of death and rebirth in good and evil destinies is due to the seeds perfumed by the member of existence, it means that it appears through the power of the perfuming of the member of existence.

All these consciousnesses are included in false imagination means that the consciousnesses of body, etc., as previously explained, are established as having the nature of false imagination that grasps the grasped and the grasper.
They have the nature of consciousness only means that the two parts appear due to false imagination, but in reality they are only consciousness.

Although there is no false grasping in good and other dharmas, the two parts appear through the power of dependent arising, and they are also only consciousness. They are unreal and do not appear as real objects.

The basis means that form, etc., which is the grasped, is called unreal, and consciousness, etc., which is the grasper, is called not real. These two are both called objects, which are imagined by the mind.
The consciousnesses that are included in false imagination are the causes and conditions for the appearance of these two, and are therefore called the basis.
Such is called the imagined pattern. As explained above, the Älaya consciousness as seed, etc., are all called the imagined pattern.

That is, in the absence of an object, only consciousness exists, and the semblance of an object appears. There is in reality no grasped object nor grasping subject, only the various consciousnesses, which are categorized as false imagination.
The semblance of an object appears in the various consciousnesses, which are the imagined object.

That is, in the dependent pattern, the nature of the semblance of an object is eternally nonexistent. The images manifested in the mind and its activities that have the dependent pattern as their object are eternally nonexistent in the imagined pattern. The true nature of reality is revealed, and this is called the perfected pattern.
Also, all dharmas are born from causes and conditions, and their nature is consciousness only. You should realize that they are all called the dependent pattern.
The semblance of an object that appears due to the error of imagination should be understood as the imagined pattern.
The true nature of reality that is revealed by the eternal nonexistence of the imagined nature in the dependent nature is to be known as the characteristic of the perfected.
The appearance of the object and the subject that is established by the power of the continuity of the self of the mirage is to be known as the characteristic of the dependent.
The appearance of the thing that is imagined to really exist is to be known as the characteristic of the imagined.
The ultimate nonexistence of the imagined water in the mirage is to be known as the characteristic of the perfected.

The characteristic of the imagined is the nature of the imagined, the characteristic of the dependent is the nature of the dependent and is also called the nature of discrimination, and the characteristic of the perfected is the nature of the perfected and is also called the nature of the essence of dharmas. These three are the three dharmas that are to be known, eliminated, and realized.

The treatise says:
Herein, the consciousness of the body, the experiencer, and the receiver should be known as the six internal sense bases such as the eyes.
The consciousness that is received by them should be known as the six external sense bases such as form.
The consciousness that is able to receive should be known as the six consciousness sense bases such as the eye consciousness.
The remaining consciousnesses should be known as distinctions of these various consciousnesses.
The commentary says:
These various consciousnesses refer to the body, etc. as the first, and the able to receive as the last, as explained above.

As for the differences, they are the different natures of these consciousnesses, that is, because in these conditioned consciousnesses there are differences of past, present, and future activity. On the basis of these differences, the consciousness that manifests images of the three time periods is established.
In these consciousnesses there are differences of one, etc., and on the basis of these differences, the consciousness that manifests images of number is established.
In the consciousness that is perceived there are differences of high and low, etc., and on the basis of these differences, the consciousness that manifests images of place is established.
The other images should be understood in the same way.
The Treatise says that
these consciousnesses are all consciousness only, because there is absolutely no real external world.
What examples are there to prove this?
You should understand that dreams, etc., are examples that prove this, that is, just as in a dream there is absolutely no external world, there is only consciousness alone.

Although there are images of various forms, sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, houses, forests, earth, and mountains that appear to be external objects, there are absolutely no real external objects in a dream.
This example shows that you should understand that at all times and places there is only consciousness.
By the words and so on, one should understand that there are also analogies such as illusion, deception, mirage, and cataract.

If at the time of awakening, all times and places are like dreams and so on, and there is only consciousness, then just as one awakens from a dream and realizes that in the dream there was only consciousness, why is it not so at the time of awakening?
At the time of awakening to true wisdom, it is also so. Just as this awakening does not occur while in a dream, but occurs when one awakens from a dream,
so too, this awakening does not occur before one awakens to true wisdom, but occurs when one awakens to true wisdom.
The commentary says:
All are only consciousness, and there is no meaning at all.
The analogy of dreams and so on is used to illustrate this because it is commonly established.
The text on like in a dream is easy to understand and does not need to be explained again.

The Sutra of the Ten Grounds, in that sutra it expounds the meaning of the ten stages of the bodhisattva. Like the impure image of a skeleton or a woman that appears to a practitioner of meditation.

The treatise says:
If the dependent nature is really only consciousness, and is the basis for the manifestation of objects, how does it become the dependent nature?
For what reason is it called the dependent nature?
It is called the dependent nature because it arises from the seeds perfumed by itself, and arises in dependence on conditions.
Because it has no power to remain naturally after the moment of arising, it is called the dependent nature.
The commentary says:
How does it become the dependent nature? This asks about the understood dharma.
For what reason is it called the dependent nature? This asks about the explanatory term, whether it is understood or not.
Because of these two questions, the meaning can be understood. The other two natures are also asked about in the same way.
Based on these questions, two pairs of answers are given.

From one's own perfumed seeds means arising from the perfumed seeds of the imagined names and expressions, because they depend on their own seeds and are born from others, they are called dependent origination. This explains that their essence arises in dependence on others.
After the moment of birth, they have no power to naturally abide explains that their essence abides in dependence on others.
For these two reasons, they are called dependent origination.
The treatise says:
If the imagined intrinsic nature, in dependence on dependent origination, is truly non-existent but appears as if existent, how does it become imagined?
For what reasons is it called imagined?
The mental consciousness of immeasurable aspects imagines, and the characteristics of inverted birth are called imagined.
The specific characteristics are truly non-existent, and only the imagined can be obtained. Therefore, it is called imagined.
